questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect a continuum of the R intro course with deeper knowledge of structuring a data analysis project in "real life", ie. handling, cleaning and merging multiple data files to be prepared for the statistical analysis.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to learn more about manipulating data and building functions as well as documenting using R markdown and Git. I would like to be able to do all data manipulation in R instead of SAS and make more reproducible programs using R projects and R markdown (and Git).

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to learn more about reproducible data analysis in R, better ways for data processing and how to use functions.

questions: What do you expect to learn from this course and what would you like to be able to do afterward with what you've learned?
responses: I expect to learn tools and good practice of data cleaning and data management. I would like to be able to take on smaller tasks of data management without being insecure about potential mistakes.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: 1. having pre-course tasks in general is good (we come prepared). 2. Good descriptions and links to previous course material.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Clear description on what to do and links to nice descriptions if something is new.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Clear instructions, easy to navigate with links to the beginner course.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Clear instructions. Nothing to comment on :)

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Everything

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Everything! All steps are very well-explained. As an intermediate R user who learned mostly from trial-and-error, this is the guide I was lacking when I introduced myself to R. I especially like the section on what to do if something doesn't work/how not to panic + explanation of why using formalized version control is essential. Language is gentle and doesn't talk down to the inexperienced user.

questions: In your opinion, what worked well?
responses: Good descriptions!

responses: Great instructions, easy to follow, also good content for a pre-course (setting up the project and familiarizing with data)

responses: Instruction were clear

responses: It is a very detailed and well-written guide.

In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Be sure that everybody long time before the course is advised to get new versions of R and R-studio. In Region H it takes weeks or months to get permissions. I had to download it to my private computer. I was put on the course from the waiting list, so I did not have a lot of time to prepare with new versions.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Difficult to assess how much of the tasks had been done, because of build-in links to rather long texts. Including all material in the same page/including a table of contents with estimated time for reading of each section, may have helped.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: Having a "go/no-go" example of the functions you have to call to see if the project is set up correctly. (fx. maybe an example of what the expected output is when running r3::check_setup()). I had to update certain packages before getting the "a-OK"-checklist.

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: How to pull and push to github, I cannot push those buttons so I need to figure it out myself. It is just mentioned in the intro precourse material, but there is no guide

questions: In your opinion, what could be improved?
responses: I think it is already well organized
